newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy car mart needs more than stop-gap aid - union.
newsitem.headline: Italy car mart needs more than stop-gap aid - union.

text.p: Poor Italian car sales data for November and specially a fall in the Fiat group's market share show the domestic market needs more than just stop-gap measures to boost flagging sales, a regional leader of the Italian FIOM metalworkers' union said.

The data showed the Turin-based carmaker had problems with competitiveness "which can't be tackled just with stop-gap measures to boost demand or, worse still, with recessive wage policies which ignore the efforts and professionality of workers," said Giorgio Cremaschi, FIOM secretary in the northwest Piedmont region where Fiat is based.
Italian metalworkers' unions are currently in deadlock with employers, including Fiat, in a dispute over wage contracts.
"Extraordinary measures involving industrial policies are necessary when it comes down to it," Cremaschi said in a statement.
Unions and auto sector research groups have called for government incentives to revive flagging Italian car sales.
Transport ministry data on Tuesday showed Italian new car registrations in November fell 11.44 percent year-on-year with Fiat car group marques posting a 17.1 percent decline.
Fiat group's market share fell to 45.63 percent from 48.75 percent in November 1995.
Cremaschi said Fiat was losing out in terms of market share "especially to products of companies whose employees are paid higher wages and have better working conditions."
